Comment:
A game of the King's Indian April 2007 mini-tournament which had the four-pawn-variation as motive.
I add the Spanish comments by migchess20 and the English by carokant.

migchess20: Creo que es mejor mantener el par de alfiles para un final y no hacer el cambio por el caballo. es mas fuerte el par de alfiles que alfil y caballo.
migchess20: Creo que es mejor mantener el par de alfiles para un final y no hacer el cambio por el caballo. es mas fuerte el par de alfiles que alfil y caballo.

White has an advanced free pawn, pressure on the f-file. The weak point could be the open d4-g1 diagonal. 
Black has a strong bishop on g7 and also can occupy open files. The black queen has good chances via h4 on the 4th row.

Covers f7.
Now black had the idea: give a rook for the bishop and then skewer the rook/queen to the king with the bishop! Which rook should I take??
...but white can give his rook back for the bishop appearing on d4 which would put white's queen in a dominating position.
...but white can give his rook back for the bishop appearing on d4 which would put white's queen in a dominating position.

...the white rook can retreat and in the same time protect the bishop. So: always think tactical move chains UNTIL THE VERY END!
